name: 2-fluoroquinoline-3-boronic acid
Reason: 2-fluoroquinoline-3-boronic acid has a melting point that can be predicted by analyzing its structural components. The basic unit for this compound is quinoline, which has a melting point of 100.5 °C (according to the CRC Handbook of Chemistry and Physics, 49th Edition, 1968-1969). The fluorine atom increases the melting point due to the increased molecular weight and electronegativity, which raises the hydrogen bonding potential. The boronic acid group also contributes to the melting point due to its ability to form hydrogen bonds and increase molecular weight. The presence of two fluorine atoms and a boronic acid group can be estimated to add approximately +20 °C and +10 °C, respectively, to the melting point.
